hints.content:
We can turn the rule into numbers and math symbols:

Rule: $\maroonD{\text{Multiply }} \blueD x \maroonD{\text{ by 2}}$.  Then $\greenD{\text{add 5}}$ to the result to get $\goldD y$.

$\blueD x \maroonD{\times 2} \greenD{+5} = \goldD y$

Now we can use the rule to  complete the  table: 

$x$ | |$y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$\blueD0$ |  $\blueD0 \maroonD{\times2}\greenD{+5} =  \goldD5$ | $\goldD5$
$\blueD1$ |  $\blueD1 \maroonD{\times2}\greenD{+5} =  \goldD7$  | $\goldD7$
$\blueD2$ | $\blueD2 \maroonD{\times2}\greenD{+5} =  \goldD9$ |$\goldD9$

Each pair of $x$ and $y$ values in the table represents an ordered pair and a point on the graph. 

The ordered pairs are:  $(0, 5), (1, 7),$ and $(2, 9)$.

Now let's graph each point.

Each $x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

To graph the point $(\blueD0,\goldD5)$, go right on the $x$-axis $\blueD0$ spaces and up on the $y$-axis $\goldD5$ spaces.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2d46d33843b8feb5d4173ac37d1295a7f808c1e0)

To graph the point $(\blueD1,\goldD7)$, go right on the $x$-axis $\blueD1$ space and up on the $y$-axis $\goldD7$ spaces.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/556d62ec8af9c231a486e838fcd7f2253f41db3d)

To graph the point $(\blueD2,\goldD9)$, go right on the $x$-axis $\blueD2$ spaces and up on the $y$-axis $\goldD9$ spaces.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/810c2885cdfe5fe1e9427c1780a6e6b6dc6fc775)

Here are the completed table and graph:

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$0$ | $5$
$1$ |  $7$
$2$ |  $9$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8b7b764f21c0eada3d11e163c927153d00844e40)

question.content:
The following rule describes the relationship between $x$ and $y$.

*Rule: To find $y$ multiply $x$ by $2$ and then subtract $1$.*

**Complete the table for the given rule.**

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ | [[☃ numeric-input 1]]
$3$ | [[☃ numeric-input 2]]
$5$ | [[☃ numeric-input 3]]


**Select the graph that shows the relationship.**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
First, let's identify the missing $\purpleD{y}$-coordinates.

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$\redE2$ | $\purpleD{?}$
$\redE3$ | $\purpleD{?}$
$\redE4$ | $\purpleD{?}$

###$(\redE2, \square )$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6d0ae9ccd5fe4636087495e07222a77447b299f0)

So when the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{2}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{6}$.

###$(\redE3, \square)$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/997d7b009a7559b6c5c87839c8a5be90e8c0d119)

When the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{3}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{4}$.

###$(\redE4, \square )$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cc9bdaee3da6c9584744d79aaba6f10bbe4336c6)

When the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{4}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{2}$.

Here is the completed table. 

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$\redE2$ | $\purpleD{6}$
$\redE3$ | $\purpleD{4}$
$\redE4$ | $\purpleD{2}$

Now, let's try each rule to see whether it works for all $3$ coordinates.

|| **Multiply $x$ by $2$. Add $2$ to the product to get $y$.** ||
$x$ | $y$ | Matches graph?
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\redE{2}$ | $(2 \times \redE{2})+2=\purpleD{6}$ | Yes
$\redE{3}$ | $(2 \times \redE{3})+2=\purpleD{8}$ | No
$\redE{4}$ | $(2 \times \redE{4})+2=\purpleD{10}$ | No

This rule does *not work* for all of the values.

|| **Multiply $x$ by $2$. Subtract the product from $10$ to get $y$.** ||
$x$ | $y$ | Matches graph?
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\redE{2}$ | $10-(2 \times \redE{2})=\purpleD{6}$ | Yes
$\redE{3}$ | $10-(2 \times \redE{3})=\purpleD{4}$ | Yes
$\redE{4}$ | $10-(2 \times \redE{4})=\purpleD{2}$ | Yes

This rule works for all of the values.

This is the completed table.

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$2$ | $6$
$3$ | $4$
$4$ | $2$

The rule that describes the relationship between $x$ and $y$ is, "Multiply $x$ by $2$. Subtract the product from $10$ to get $y$."

###$(\redE1, \square )$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bf7ac6ea9692cb52e96489eb10bd282305acb7d2)

When the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{1}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{0}$.

###$(\redE2, \square )$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/db8c2213e45cdb7656c6e8afd6f0c03b355423f1)

So when the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{2}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{3}$.

###$(\redE3, \square)$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1e8710579b5b4b5aa0da7a49e51314943392fd57)

When the value of $\redE{x}=\redE{3}$, then $\purpleD{y}=\purpleD{6}$.

Here is the completed table. 

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$\redE1$ | $\purpleD{0}$
$\redE2$ | $\purpleD{3}$
$\redE3$ | $\purpleD{6}$

Now, let's try each rule to see whether it works for all $3$ coordinates.

|| **Multiply $x$ by $0$. Add $3$ to the product to get $y$.** ||
$x$ | $y$ | Matches graph?
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\redE{1}$ | $(0 \times \redE{1})+3=\purpleD{3}$ | No
$\redE{2}$ | $(0 \times \redE{2})+3=\purpleD{3}$ | Yes
$\redE{3}$ | $(0\times \redE{3})+3=\purpleD{3}$ | No

This rule does *not work* for all of the values.

|| **Multiply $x$ by $3$. Then subtract $3$ from the product to get $y$.** ||
$x$ | $y$ | Matches graph?
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\redE{1}$ | $(3 \times \redE{1})-3=\purpleD{0}$ | Yes
$\redE{2}$ | $(3 \times \redE{2})-3=\purpleD{3}$ | Yes
$\redE{3}$ | $(3\times \redE{3})-3=\purpleD{6}$ | Yes

This rule works for all of the values.

This is the completed table.

$x$ | $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ | $0$
$2$ | $3$
$3$ | $6$

The rule that describes the relationship between $x$ and $y$ is, "Multiply $x$ by $3$. Then subtract $3$ from the product to get $y$."
